channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Mart√≠nez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Supreme Court rules administration can end protected status for Venezuelans for now
item.description: The Supreme Court ruled Monday that the Trump administration, for now, can end the safeguard known as Temporary Protected Status for about 350,000 Venezuelans living in the U.S.

item.title: Russia builds up military presence along borders with NATO member countries
item.description: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with Fiona Hill, senior fellow with the Brookings Institution, about Russia's military buildup along its borders with NATO members.

item.title: Trump and Putin talk about ending war in Ukraine, but there's no ceasefire agreement
item.description: President Trump spoke with Russian President Vladimir Putin for more than two hours on Monday and claimed progress toward ending the war in Ukraine. But Putin did not agree to an immediate ceasefire.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Trump and Putin talk about negotiating ceasefire in Ukraine, Israel faces unprecedented pressure from allies over the war in Gaza, a look at links between climate change and tornadoes in the U.S.

item.title: Journalist Karen Hao discusses her book 'Empire of AI'
item.description: Journalist Karen Hao has written a book called "Empire of AI," which details the world of Sam Altman's OpenAI.

item.title: A brain dead pregnant woman is being kept on life support, raising legal questions
item.description: A woman in Georgia has been declared brain dead, but she's being kept on life support because she's pregnant. The case is raising complicated legal questions about restrictive abortion laws.

item.title: A look at the potential impacts of proposed Medicaid cuts
item.description: NPR speaks with health economist Lindsay Allen, assistant professor at Northwestern University's Feinberg School of Medicine, about the impact of proposed cuts to Medicaid being debated in Congress.

item.title: Large tornado outbreaks are becoming more common. But it's unclear why
item.description: It's getting more common for a lot of tornadoes to form over a big area in a short period of time. But the total number of tornadoes each year in the U.S. is stable.

item.title: New book alleges aides hid former President Biden's declining health
item.description: A new book details an alleged cover-up within the White House surrounding the declining health of former President Biden. NPR speaks with the authors, CNN's Jake Tapper and Axios' Alex Thompson.

item.title: Political commentator Bakari Sellers discusses how Democrats can regain voter trust
item.description: NPR speaks with political commentator and former Democratic state lawmaker Bakari Sellers about how Democrats can regain trust after a book alleged aides hid former President Biden's declining health.
